subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Let A and B be linear transformations from V to V. Prove that the composition of these transformations is associative: (AB)C = A(BC).
hints: Check if the order matters by considering a specific example.
Use the definition of matrix multiplication to expand the product.
Show that the associativity holds for any linear transformation C
solutionHtml:
To prove the associativity, we can use the definition of matrix multiplication:

\( (AB)C = A(BC) \)

Expanding the product on the right-hand side, we get:

\( A(B \cdot C) = A(\sum_{i} B \cdot c_i e_i) \)

Using the linearity of A, we can rewrite this as:

\( \sum_{i} (AB) \cdot c_i e_i \)

This is equal to:

\( (AB)C = \sum_{i} (AB) \cdot c_i e_i \)

Thus, we have shown that the composition of linear transformations is associative.

",
commonMistakes: Forgetting to check if the order matters

subject: linear_algebra

problem.statementHtml: Let T1 and T2 be linear transformations from ℝ^n to ℝ^m. Prove that the composition of these transformations, denoted as (T2 ∘ T1), can be represented by the matrix product A2A1, where A1 and A2 are the matrices representing T1 and T2 respectively.
hints: Start by considering a vector v in ℝ^n. Apply T1 to get Av, then apply T2 to get (T2 ∘ T1)v.
Think about how matrix multiplication works for vectors.
Use the properties of linear transformations to relate the composition to the matrices
problem.solutionHtml:
To prove that the composition (T2 ∘ T1) can be represented by the matrix product A2A1, we start with a vector v in ℝ^n. We apply T1 to get Av, then apply T2 to get (T2 ∘ T1)v.

By definition of linear transformation, we have:

(T2 ∘ T1)v = T2(T1v) = T2(Av)

Now, since T2 is a linear transformation, we can represent it by a matrix A2. So, we have:

(T2 ∘ T1)v = A2Av

Next, we apply the properties of linear transformations to relate this composition to the matrices. Specifically, we know that applying T1 to v and then applying A2 to the result is equivalent to applying A2A1 to v.

So, we can write:

(T2 ∘ T1)v = (A2A1)v

This shows that the composition of linear transformations (T2 ∘ T1) can be represented by the matrix product A2A1.

commonMistakes: Forgetting to apply the transformation twice, once for each composition step
Not recognizing that the order of transformations matters

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Given two linear transformations A and B, find the composition of these transformations as a matrix product.
hints: Think about the order in which you multiply matrices.
Use the definition of matrix multiplication to help you compute the result.
Check your answer by verifying that it satisfies the expected properties.
solutionHtml:
To find the composition AB, we need to multiply the matrices representing A and B. The order of multiplication matters, so we do this:

\[AB = egin{bmatrix} a_{11} & a_{12} \ a_{21} & a_{22} \end{bmatrix} egin{bmatrix} b_{11} & b_{12} \ b_{21} & b_{22} \end{bmatrix}\]

The resulting matrix is the product of the two matrices:

\[AB = egin{bmatrix} a_{11}b_{11} + a_{12}b_{21} & a_{11}b_{12} + a_{12}b_{22} \ a_{21}b_{11} + a_{22}b_{21} & a_{21}b_{12} + a_{22}b_{22} \end{bmatrix}\]

The final answer is the matrix product AB.

",
